text: <@U08CFV27P|wilfra> has joined the channel
<@U08FSH97D|matan.field> has joined the channel
<@U08BY8MGV>: I received the invite and am able to edit. But, it will not happen in the next few hours. Had a half a day travel and returned just now.
<@U07GDL0H5>: I will take a shot with a couple of documents tomorrow. Hope that is fine and the docs will be available for some updation.
I would create a new tab for whatever you do <@U08DH3ESU> and/or insert comments on my tabs so it's easier to track changes
anyone have a sense of how much bandwidth costs might be to run a node, and how that may factor into splits?

<@U08EZP01H>: totally depends on the popularity ... i'm pretty sure at first, the cost will be basically negligible, although to have a reliable node you really want to put things on a server with good uptime somewhere, so it's not 0.
assuming we start with pure text content, the bandwidth costs should be extremely low

obviously that could change if the thing becomes popular. nodes can filter content, so they don't have to download/upload everything. that can keep the costs reasonable for people who don't want to host everything.
<@U08CG8V89|c_prompt> has joined the channel
<@U08FW063C|jordan> has joined the channel
<@U08FWU9ST|primavera> has joined the channel

<@U07GDL0H5>: <@U08EZP01H> nodes are likely to quite greedy in terms of finding the content that will benefit it the most, number of peer connections and latency might factor as much as bandwidth. I'd certainly expect to run a node on a $5/mo droplet

<@U08ERPTQF|paul_xbt> uploaded a file: <https://dattnetwork.slack.com/files/paul_xbt/F08FX5DKQ/Another_attempt_at_a_DATT_business_model|Another attempt at a DATT business model> and commented: It's a longer read, a bit more perspectives, than business model per-se. This builds on <@U08BY8MGV>'s work to define money flows, but I've changed how the money flows to be more organic...

file.name: Another_attempt_at_a_DATT_business_model
file.title: Another attempt at a DATT business model
file.preview:
Another attempt at a DATT business model

Premise

Users upvote and gild posts - both of which pay in favor of the Author
Authors post content and may also apportion some profit or attach a bounty - to incentivise nodes to propagate the content
Mods curate listings of content into collectives - this benefits users who consume this listing, and also nodes that want to serve good content
…

initial_comment.comment: It's a longer read, a bit more perspectives, than business model per-se. This builds on <@U08BY8MGV>'s work to define money flows, but I've changed how the money flows to be more organic...

text: This latest model includes the concept of subscriptions as discussed with <@U08E5P0BZ>  <@U08DD8LNP> & <@U08EZP01H> last night in <#C08FM0F6G>

comment.comment: <@U08DD8LNP>: from your 9 years on reddit, does this model and underlying perspectives seem right?

text: can someone explain the idea of the bounty to me? As I understand it it's an extra incentive for nodes to host/propagate your content. So if my blog post isn't getting any traction I can say, "I will give you 60% of all my tips if you host this post" or "I will pay you 50,000 bits to host thids post"
is that wrong?

<@U08EZP01H|darrenm> commented on <@U08ERPTQF|paul_xbt>'s file <https://dattnetwork.slack.com/files/paul_xbt/F08FX5DKQ/Another_attempt_at_a_DATT_business_model|Another attempt at a DATT business model>: The user-first approach here makes my inner UX nerd happy. I think this will tie in nicely with creating personas and use-cases.  It's also the first practical explanation of our stack as a user would see it.

comment.comment: The user-first approach here makes my inner UX nerd happy. I think this will tie in nicely with creating personas and use-cases.  It's also the first practical explanation of our stack as a user would see it.

text: <@U08FELGRX> that's what my understanding was, but if that's the case  the higher the bounty more nodes will pick it up just by the bounty pricing
Thanks <@U08EZP01H> :)
<@U08FELGRX>: the bounty can be a portion of the upvotes, or extra funds the author put in when they posted. Nodes would have to be actively serving the content to claim a portion of the bounty
so could the bounty be "eaten up" by the first nodes that host, or the more nodes that host the smaller portion each node gets?
Would there be a check and balance at some point with bounties? I'm curious about playing with reductio ad absurdum to see what happens if someone dropped $10k and asked for a 0% cut.
It is weighted in favor of the early nodes, but it also has a time element that the nodes aren't getting much of the bounty unless they stick around
And yes more nodes equals smaller portion, so nodes are motivated to find fresh content to stake their claim
<@U08EZP01H>: good point, we should consider a ridiculous bounty may drive different behavior
also rich people/corporations could just pay mass amounts to have their content seen first/most often

<@U08FELGRX>: indeed part of the motivation to have bounties, is this acts as a bridge for mainstream publishers to 'promote' their content, but users aren't forced to see it - it's opt-in based on which Collective you follow
<@U08ERPTQF>:  so users can opt-in to see regular contents along with 'promoted'?
Brb

Well, consider a scenario: Sarah Palin could spend $1m to promote her content across the network. The nodes would eat it up for the profit, but the users would (I imagine) downvote this into oblivion.  Perhaps that gives insight into what we should do with downvotes.
<@U08EZP01H>:  that's a good example :simple_smile:

If you're paying tons of money for distribution, and the nodes are eating it up for obvious reasons, but the users hate seeing your garbage posts... how can we make sure the network will self correct? What do we want to have happen to Palin's $1m for trying to 'force' a message on a network that disagrees?

I think the big remaining question here is whether the 'customers' of this project are the Nodes or the Mods. We would prioritize propogation of content across the network and not content curation if we choose Nodes and we would focus on curation incentives and content creators if we choose Mods
<@U08EZP01H>: can the user have a filter option to block the forced content?

As the content is downvoted, nodes may take whatever portion of the bounty they are due and move on. Users might also want in on the bounty (which they can do with their client) so at least opportunistic users were reached.
Mostly I think this teaches Palin not to suck so much that even with a large bounty she didn't reach the desired audience
Users can be Nodes & Mods as they desire
<@U08DD8LNP>: is keen on all users having a say in their filtering of content - which I strongly agree with
Oh yea. It gets dangerous when you give anyone else sorting power.
<@U07GDL0H5>: Will we be hosting a wallet that the end user can use?
Or will they need to connect a wallet somehow
the wallet lives client-side. if they are running the app for the first time, a new randomly generated master private key is generated automatically
no one but the user ever sees that private key
it can be stored client-side in IndexedDB or localstorage ... and presumably also stored on other nodes in encrypted form
though i guess they better have the key or they can't decrypt it
so they really need to write it down
it will take the form of a BIP 39 mnemonic
<@U08G10908|christophera> has joined the channel

That's a pretty difficult thing to get lots of users to do. I wonder how Zapchain does it. Are they holding the bits you received from tipping in their own wallet or at Coinbase? In order to send funds, they require you to connect a Coinbase account
<@U08C9ML1Y|chiguireitor> has joined the channel

My thought on preserving identity /wallet was to allow the user to log in to dropbox or another cloud provider to back up their keys (encrypted with a password) in cases where they aren't prepared to manually handle export and backup.
